Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41154  
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
October 2010 
 
 
 
Nepal: Energy Sector Capacity Building 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 30 September 2010) 
Currency Unit –  Nepalese rupee/s (Nre/NRs) 
NRe1.00 =  $0.0136 
$1.00 =  NRs73.37 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DOED  –  Department of Electricity Development 
  ETFC  –  Electricity Tariff Fixation Commission  
  MOE  –  Ministry of Energy 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Capacity development technical assistance (CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Energy (energy sector development) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity Development (institutional development), economic 
growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling business 
environment), environmental sustainability (natural resources 
conservation) 
Location impact  –  National (high impact) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  S. H. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  Y. Zhai, Energy Division, SARD  
   
Team leader  P. Wijayatunga, Senior Energy Specialist, SARD 
Team members  L. George, Energy Specialist, SARD 
  M.S. Parwez, Program/Project Implementation Officer, SARD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation of or 
reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development Bank does 
not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Following a request from the Government of Nepal, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
included capacity development technical assistance (TA) in the country partnership strategy, 
2010–2012 for Nepal to support Nepal's energy sector in 2010.1 During consultation missions in 
2010, ADB and the Ministry of Energy (MOE) discussed the capacity development needs of 
Nepal's public energy institutions and identified broad areas of possible intervention. 
 
2.  ADB fielded a TA fact-finding mission on 19–23 July 2010 to design the content and 
implementation arrangements of the TA. In a letter dated 10 August 2010, the Ministry of 
Finance confirmed the aide mémoire containing the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, terms of reference of consultants, and design and 
monitoring framework (Appendix 1).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Given Nepal's vast hydropower potential, the country's energy sector is poised to make 
a strong contribution to the country's economic development. But years of underinvestment in 
electricity generation have led to supply shortages. Investments have not kept up with growth in 
demand, which increases by 9%–10% annually. The Nepal Electricity Authority has performed 
poorly and incurred heavy financial losses. A poor regulatory environment has added to the 
sector's problems. Nepal's electricity supply system is among the least reliable in South Asia, 
characterized  by  frequent  unscheduled  interruptions  and long  periods  of  scheduled  supply 
outages.  While  56%  of  households  have  electricity,  the  electrification  process  has  stalled, 
mainly  because  of  low  generation  capacity.  A  sector  that  has  the  potential  to  contribute 
significant foreign exchange earnings through power exports instead must import energy at 
great cost from neighboring India. 
 
4.  In July 2007, the National Planning Commission released the 3-year interim plan, 2008–
2010,3 which identified major proposed development interventions in Nepal. In the long term, 
the plan envisions using the country's water resources to meet domestic electricity demand and 
increase foreign exchange earnings from the export of surplus power. The targets set for the 
sector in the long term (up to 2027) are (i) generating 4,000 MW of power in 2027 to meet 
domestic demand; (ii) expanding electricity services to cover 75% of the population through the 
national grid, 20% of the population through isolated small and micro-hydropower systems, and 
5% of the population through alternative energy sources; and (iii) increasing annual per capita 
electricity consumption to 400 kWh from the 71 kWh (2006). 
 
5.  The  key  strategies  adopted  by  the  government  to  achieve  these  targets  will  be  (i) 
improving  regulation  of  businesses  involved  in  electricity  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution; (ii) encouraging investments in hydropower by adopting a one-stop-shop approach 
so that investors can obtain all approvals from a single agency; and (iii) expanding the capacity 
of electricity generation. Attracting private investments in hydropower will be vital to satisfying 
the large investment needs of the energy sector. 
 
                                                 
1   ADB. 2009. Nepal: Country Partnership Strategy, 2010–2012.  Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 August 2010. 
3  National Planning Commission. 2008. Three Year Interim Plan (2007/08–2009/10). Nepal: National Planning 
Commission.

2   
6.  ADB TA on promoting private participation in Nepal's electricity sector4 identified many 
barriers to the development of large hydropower projects in Nepal. These barriers included (i) a 
lack of a clear policy, legal, and regulatory framework governing hydropower; (ii) a lack of 
conducive licensing terms and conditions; (iii) an absence of cost-based mechanisms for setting 
both wholesale and retail tariffs, where power purchase costs are passed through to consumers; 
and  (iv)  off-takers  not  being  informed  about  the  project  developer’s  cost  base  and  cost 
escalations over time. Overcoming these barriers will require (i) improved energy policies and 
regulations, and (ii) more extensive preparatory work on projects up for bidding. 
 
7.  Addressing these issues in a manner consistent with the government's energy strategy 
will require improving the capacity of institutions—particularly those dealing with hydropower—
to develop and implement effective energy policies and regulations. Capacity building efforts 
should focus on building human resource capacity and providing software support on (i) energy 
policy and regulation, and (ii) hydropower planning and development. The performance of the 
Department of Electricity Development (DOED) should be improved and its ability to respond to 
emerging hydropower development needs should be strengthened. Efforts to build capacity in 
setting effective energy policies should target the newly formed MOE. The MOE should be 
trained to ensure that the DOED carries out its regulatory functions within an overall policy 
framework set by the MOE. Ensuring revenue recovery in projects under consideration is vital to 
attracting private investment and ultimately ensuring the success of these projects. Ensuring 
revenue recovery will require that consumer energy tariffs are set at sufficient levels. Building 
the capacity of the Electricity Tariff Fixations Commission (ETFC), the agency in charge of 
setting consumer tariffs, will therefore be critical. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be rapid development of hydropower generation in Nepal. The 
outcome of the TA will be enhanced capability of the MOE, the ETFC, and the DOED in 
hydropower policy making, regulation, planning, and investment promotion. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Updated hydropower development plans of DOED will help the developers of large 
hydropower projects identify and implement on a priority basis the most economically viable 
projects. The evaluation tools will help the DOED accurately examine the information provided 
by the hydropower project developers. The monitoring tools will help DOED to closely follow the 
progress of project implementation. The policy and regulatory environment will be enhanced 
through capacity building within the MOE, the ETFC, and the DOED. 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. During phase I, a capacity development 
advisor will identify the capacity building requirements of the MOE, the ETFC, and the DOED. A 
capacity development coordinator, with the support of the advisor, will then identify specific 
training requirements, select the tools and experts to be utilized, and coordinate subsequent 
activities under the TA.  
 
                                                 
4   ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Promoting Private Sector Participation in the Power Sector. Manila 
(TA 4997-NEP).

3
11.  Phase  II  activities  will  include  (i)  developing  policies,  plans,  and  evaluation  and 
monitoring tools for hydropower projects; (ii) standardizing documentation submitted for project 
approval and, where possible, methodologies for evaluating private hydropower projects; (iii) 
assisting the DOED in negotiating at least one large hydropower project based on a public–
private partnership (PPP); and (iv) conducting in-house and external training and exchange 
programs for MOE, ETFC and DOED staff arranged by the capacity development coordinator. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $700,000 equivalent, of which $600,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV),  and 
$100,000 will be financed by the Government of Nepal in the form of in-kind contributions such 
as counterpart staff and office accommodation. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The executing agency of the TA will be the MOE. The TA will begin in December 2010 
and will be completed on 31 July 2012. The TA will require the services of four international 
consultants for a total of 11 person-months, and one national consultant for 4 person-months. 
The  consulting  team  will  include  (i)  an  energy  sector  capacity  development  advisor 
(international), (ii) a capacity development coordinator (international), (iii) a hydropower policy 
and  planning  specialist  (international),  (iv)  a  project  evaluation  and  monitoring  specialist 
(international), and (v) a legal expert (national). ADB will recruit the consultants in accordance 
with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Considering the urgency of this TA, and considering that the tasks of the consultants will be 
mostly independent and can be undertaken in parallel, all five consultants will be recruited 
individually.  Disbursement  under  the  TA  will be  made  in  accordance  the  ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The equipment 
purchased under the TA will be turned over to the DOED upon completion of the TA. 
 
14.  Every consultant except the capacity development advisor will separately submit an 
inception  report  (within  1  month  of  the  start  of  the  assignment),  an  interim  report  (after 
completing 50% of the allocated person-months), and a final report (after completing 90% of the 
allocated person-months). The capacity development advisor will provide inputs to the capacity 
development coordinator, whose reports will cover overall progress of the TA activities. 
 
15.  The  capacity  development  coordinator  will  present  to  ADB  and  the  government  a 
summary of each training activity. The outputs of the consultants will be presented to the 
relevant stakeholders during in-country seminars. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
Nepal for Energy Sector Capacity Building, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Introduction 
 
1.  The consultants for the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed Nepal Energy Sector 
Capacity  Building  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  will  build  capacity  and  support  hardware 
development for institutions involved in setting policies and regulations, planning, and/or promoting 
investments  in  hydropower.  Efforts  will  focus  on  (i)  developing  streamlined  procedures  for 
hydropower  development  in  Nepal,  (ii)  developing  a  long-term  national  investment  plan  for 
hydropower,  and  (iii)  increasing  the  number  of  public–private  partnerships  in  hydropower 
generation.  The  Department  of  Electricity  Development  (DOED)  needs  enhanced  capacity  to 
assess  and  monitor  the  development  of  hydropower  project  proposals  and  respond  to  other 
emerging needs. The Ministry of Energy (MOE) and Electricity Tariff Fixation Commission (ETFC) 
need enhanced capacity to carry out their policy making and regulatory roles, while ensuring the 
financial sustainability of hydropower projects. The outcome of the TA will be enhanced capability 
of the MOE, the ETFC, and the DOED in hydropower policy making, regulation, planning, and 
investment promotion. The MOE will be the executing agency. 
 
2.  The consultants will assess the capacity building needs in the MOE, the DOED and the 
ETFC relating to hydropower development, and recommend training programs and other measures 
to address these needs. Furthermore, the consultants will arrange and coordinate these training 
and  other  capacity  building  programs.  The  TA  will  require  the  services  of  four  international 
consultants and one national consultant for a total of 15 person-months on an intermittent basis. 
The consulting team will include (i) an energy sector capacity development advisor (international), 
(ii)  a  capacity  development  coordinator  (international),  (iii)  a  hydropower  policy  and  planning 
specialist (international), (iv) a project evaluation and monitoring specialist (international), and (v) a 
legal expert (national). ADB will recruit the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). All five consultants will be recruited 
individually.  
 
3.  The international capacity development coordinator will be the team leader and will facilitate 
communication between ADB, the MOE, the DOED and the ETFC. The team leader will deliver the 
expected outputs and progress reports to ADB. 
 
B.   Scope of Work 
 
4.  The duration of the TA is 20 months from the start of services. The energy sector capacity 
development advisor and capacity development coordinator are expected to participate in the TA 
inception mission as mission members and consult with the Ministry of Energy, the DOED and the 
ETFC to identify their capacity development needs and arrange programs based on those needs. 
 
1.  Capacity Development Coordinator (International, 2 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant should have a degree and will act as the team leader and coordinator of all 
TA  activities  under  the  guidance  of  the  energy  sector  capacity  development  advisor.  The 
consultant should have experience in coordinating capacity development programs in the energy 
sector in developing countries, preferably in South Asia. Among other tasks, the consultant will:

8  Appendix 3 
(i)  Provide an inception report within 1 month of the start of the assignment outlining the 
activities to be carried out and the timeframes in consultation with the MOE and the 
DOED; 
(ii)  Coordinate the activities of the hydropower planning specialist and the project 
evaluation and monitoring specialist;  
(iii)  Finalize the capacity development plan with guidance from the energy sector capacity 
development advisor; 
(iv)  Prepare an interim report; and  
(v)  Prepare progress reports on the activities and the lessons learned, and prepare a final 
report. 
 
2.  Energy Sector Capacity Development Advisor (International, 1 person-month) 
 
6.  The consultant should have extensive experience dealing in energy policy making, energy 
planning, and evaluating projects in developing countries. Among other tasks, the consultant will: 
  
(i)  Consult with the MOE, the ETFC, and the DOED to identify priority areas for capacity 
development programs; programs should include gender mainstreaming components;  
(ii)  Identify training programs and exchanges for MOE, DOED and ETFC and the 
institutions providing such services; 
(iii)  Prepare cost estimates for training programs;  
(iv)  Advise the capacity development coordinator in finalizing the capacity development 
plan; and 
(v)  Provide inputs to the inception, interim, final, and progress reports.  
 
3.  Hydropower Policy and Planning Specialist (International, 4 person-months) 
7.  The  consultant  should  have  a  degree  in  engineering  and  extensive  experience  in 
hydropower planning in developing countries. Among other tasks, the consultant will: 
 
(i)  Review the existing hydropower development plans; 
(ii)  Identify up-to-date planning tools for hydropower development and provide 
recommendations for procurement, including hardware requirements; 
(iii)  Update the input database for hydropower planning for Nepal, focusing on river-
basin-wide planning; 
(iv)  Update the plans in consultation with the stakeholders; 
(v)  Train MOE and DOED staff in using planning tools; 
(vi)  Review the barriers to implementing PPP models in hydropower identified during the 
recently concluded ADB TA on promoting private participation in Nepal's electricity 
sector 1, and propose an action plan to overcome those barriers; and 
(vii)  Provide inception, interim, and final reports on the assignment.  
 
4.  Project Evaluation and Monitoring Specialist (International, 4 person-months) 
8.  The consultant should have a degree in economics, finance, engineering, or relevant field 
and should have experience in economic and financial analysis and evaluation of hydropower 
projects in developing countries. Among other tasks, the consultant will: 
 
                                                 
1 ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Promoting Private Sector Participation in the Power Sector. Manila (TA 
4997-NEP).
